section.title: Complex Numbers

blockquote.p: Le plus court chemin entre deux vérités dans le domaine réel passe par le domaine complexe.
Between two truths of the real domain, the easiest and shortest path quite often passes through the complex domain.

section.p: One of the most basic problems in mathematics is solving equations. Equation such as x+2=3, we could solve in antiquity; x=1. And we could do it just with integers. A little harder one is 2x = 3, now we need fractions (rational numbers) to find the solution of x=\frac{3}{2}, again we could do this since antiquity. In some sense cheating, we simply said there has to be a number we get when we divide 3 by 2, and so we will call it \frac{3}{2}. The equation x^2=2 presents another conundrum. On one hand x is the length of the diagonal of a square tile of side one, so we are convinced that such a number exists. And yet it was already known to ancient greeks that there is no fraction that will work. Again we solve it by cheating a little. We call this number the square root of 2 which just means the number which when we square we get 2. OK, we got out of those difficulties relatively easy. The equation x+1=1 turned out to be a bit harder than you would have thought from the modern perspective, as it took people quite some time to treat zero as a number. Next, an equation such as x+3=2 was a problem until about the middle ages, when we decided to just bite the bullet and think of negative numbers as numbers. Nowadays you find negative numbers everywhere, quantities such as temperature can be negative. But at one time people didn't think of these as actual numbers.

All the numbers we saw up till now were real numbers. The real numbers are those numbers that can be represented as points on an infinite line. We have algebraic operations of addition and multiplication, and the real numbers satisfy many nice algebraic properties (they are a field if you heard this term).

The reals are a wonderful set of numbers and we so wish that we could work with them, but then we try to solve the equation x^2=-1, and we are in trouble again. There is no real number whose square is -1 since the square of a real number is never negative. Fear not, we have gotten out of this trouble before, we will just invent a new number. Let us call it i, although some people, especially engineers, will call it j, and some people will even just always write \sqrt{-1} instead of i. We will write i.

So, we simply start with the real numbers and we throw in i as if it were an unknown and we call the result the complex numbers complex numbers. Then, whenever we can simplify with i^2=-1, we do so. For example:
{(1+3i)}^2 = 1 + 6i +9i^2 = 1 + 6i - 9 = -8 + 6i ,
or
(1+3i)(2-5i) - 9i = 2 + 6i -5 i - 15 i^2 - 9i = 2+i + 15 - 9i = 17-8i .
A little bit of thought reveals that if we think of the operations of multiplications and addition, we can write all of the complex numbers as
x+iy
where x and y are real numbers. We will usually use the letter z or w for complex numbers. That is, we write z=x+iy. Similarly we will generally use x and y for real numbers. If z=x+iy, the number x is called the real partreal part and the number y is called the imaginary partimaginary part. We use the notation
\Re z = \Re (x+iy) = x, \qquad \Im z = \Im (x+iy) = y.
For example \Re (3-5i) = 3 and \Im (3-5i) = -5.

The terminology real, complex, and imaginary is perhaps misleading. There is nothing more imaginary about i then there is about rational numbers, roots, zero, or negative real numbers. They simply appear in different applications. They may look a little strange, a little abstract, but so did zero to the ancient greeks.

By working out the expressions we arrive at
(x+iy)+(a+ib) = (x+a) + i(y+b)
(x+iy)(a+ib) = (xa-yb) + i(xb+ya) .
We can also work out the additive inversemultiplicative inverse additive and multiplicative inverses. The additive, that is -z is really easy: Notice (x+iy)+(-x-iy) = 0, so -(x+iy) = -x-iy. The multiplicative is somewhat more difficult. Given a nonzero z we wish to find z^{-1} such that zz^{-1} = 1. It turns out that if x+iy \not=0, that is if at least one of x or y is nonzero, then
{(x+iy)}^{-1} = \frac{1}{x+iy} = \frac{x-iy}{x^2+y^2} = \frac{x}{x^2+y^2} - i \frac{y}{x^2+y^2}.
For example,
{(2+i3)}^{-1} = \frac{1}{2+i3} = \frac{2-i3}{2^2+3^2} = \frac{2}{13} - i \frac{3}{13}.
Let's test it out, using the formula for multiplication
\begin{split} (2+3i) {(2+i3)}^{-1} & = (2+3i) \left( \frac{2}{13} - i \frac{3}{13} \right) \\ & = \left( 2 \frac{2}{13} - 3 \frac{-3}{13} \right) +i \left( 2 \frac{3}{13} - 3 \frac{2}{13} \right) = 1 + 0i = 1. \end{split}

Notice that x-iy in the above formula. This is an important enough operation that we give it a name and notation. The complex conjugatecomplex conjugate or perhaps just conjugateconjugate. This operation is really new for complex numbers and you have not seen for real numbers. We usually write it with a bar over the number.
\bar{z} = \overline{x+iy} = x-iy .
So for example \overline{9-3i} = 9+3i or \overline{5i} = -5i. That is, you simply flip the sign of the imaginary part.

Complex numbers are a fieldfield of complex numbersfield just like the real numbers. As the real numbers are just part of the complex numbers we still have 0 and 1. We have additive and multiplicative inverses (see above). And they satisfy the following properties
Associative laws: z_1+(z_2+z_3) = (z_1+z_2)+z_3, \quad z_1(z_2z_3) = (z_1z_2)z_3.
Distributive law: z_1(z_2+z_3) = z_1z_2+z_1z_3.
Commutative laws: z_1+z_2 = z_2+z_1, \quad z_1z_2 = z_2z_1.
Similarly there are rules for the conjugation:
\overline{z_1+z_2} = \bar{z}_1+\bar{z}_2,\qquad \overline{z_1z_2} = \bar{z}_1\bar{z}_2,\qquad \overline{\left(\frac{1}{z}\right)} = \frac{1}{\bar{z}}.
It is easy to see that conjugation is a so called involution, that is, applying it twice gets us back to where we were:
\bar{\bar{z}} = z .
Finally, a formula which will become very useful is the following. Suppose that z=x+iy. Then
z\bar{z} = (x+iy)(x-iy) = x^2+y^2 .
Notice that this is the expression that appeared in the denominator of the multiplicative inverse. It is not hard to see why:
\frac{1}{x+iy} = \frac{1}{z} = \frac{\bar{z}}{z\bar{z}} = \frac{x-iy}{x^2+y^2} = \frac{x}{x^2+y^2} - i \frac{y}{x^2+y^2} .

And while it seems that we have just made real numbers better, there is one thing that we did lose. Real numbers are ordered in a nice way, that is, given two distinct real numbers x and y, then either x\lt y or y\lt x. For complex numbers, there is no natural order. That is, there is no way to order the numbers in a way that would play nice with the algebraic operations. It is a general fact of math (and life) that when you find a new object that does something better, you will also lose something. There is no such thing as a free lunch.

It turns out that by adding i we have not only solved the equation z^2=-1. We have ensured that all polynomial equations have solutions. This is not easy to see, but it is true. In fact, any polynomial of degree d must have exactly d roots, though some roots may be repeated. This is perhaps the main reason why complex analysis is such a powerful tool.

subsection.title: The Plane
subsection.p: The real numbers are geometrically represented by an infinite number line, real linethe real line. The complex numbers are a pair of real numbers, and as such can be represented by a two dimensional plane. That is, if z=x+iy, then z can be represented by the point (x,y) on the plane. This plane is called the complex planecomplex plane The complex plane is sometimes called the Argand planeArgand plane or the Gauss planeGauss plane.. If we will want to emphasise the variable name we may say the z-plane. The horizontal axis (the x-axis) is called the real axisreal axis and the vertical axis (the y-axis) is called the imaginary axisimaginary axis. Notice the location of the point i, that is the point (0,1) on the plane.

subsection.title: Modulus
subsection.p:
Think of a complex number z=x+iy as its position vector, that is, a vector from the origin to z. If we measure the euclidean length of this vector and we call that length the modulusmodulus. We write it as if it were the absolute value:
\abs{z} = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} .
For example \abs{2-3i} = \sqrt{2^2+{(-3)}^2} = \sqrt{13}. If you recall the last section, we find that \abs{z}=\sqrt{z\bar{z}} or \abs{z}^2=z\bar{z} (in many computations dealing with a squared quantity is easier than dealing with a square root of a quantity). Another thing to notice is that if y=0, then \abs{z} = \abs{x+0i} = \sqrt{x^2} = \abs{x}, the standard absolute value on the real numbers. So we have not confused matters by using the same notation for both. In fact, sometimes the modulus is just called the absolute valueabsolute value.

The modulus gives a distance between any two points, not just the origin and z. If z=x+iy and w=a+ib, then the distancedistance between them (using the standard euclidean distance in the plane) is
\abs{z-w} = \sqrt{{(x-a)}^2+{(y-b)}^2} .
For example, the distance between 1-2i and -3+3i is \abs{(1-2i)-(-3+3i)} = \abs{4-5i} = \sqrt{41}.

The modulus satisfies a number of useful properties. Let us list the properties that are easy to verify:
\abs{z} = \abs{\bar{z}} = \abs{-z} ,
\abs{zw} = \abs{z}\abs{w} ,
and if w \not= 0 then
\abs{\frac{1}{w}} = \frac{1}{\abs{w}} , \quad \text{and so} \quad \abs{\frac{z}{w}} = \frac{\abs{z}}{\abs{w}} .

Finally it satisfies the so-called triangle inequalitytriangle inequality.
\abs{z+w} \leq \abs{z}+\abs{w}
This inequality can also be generalized to several variables:
\abs{z_1+z_2+\cdots+z_n} \leq \abs{z_1}+\abs{z_2}+\cdots+\abs{z_n} .
Another generalization is the inverse triangle inequalityinverse triangle inequality:
\bigl\lvert \abs{z}-\abs{w} \bigr\rvert \leq \abs{z-w} .

subsection.title: Argument
subsection.p: A vector is described by two quantities, a direction and a magnitude. We have the magnitude, that is the modulus. In a two-dimensional plane a direction can be described by an angle. So let the argumentargument of z be the angle that the vector of z makes with the positive real axis. We will use a positive number if the angle is in the counterclockwise direction, and a negative number if the angle is in the clockwise direction. The modulus and the argument are simply the two numbers describing the point z using polar coordinates.
FIXME: draw including the examples below

So the argument of a positive real number is 0. The argument of i is \frac{\pi}{2}. The argument of 1+i is \frac{\pi}{4}. The argument of -i is \frac{-\pi}{2}. And the argument of a negative real number is \pi or -\pi.

Notice that the angle is not unique. For example i could also have argument \frac{\pi}{2}+2\pi = \frac{5 \pi}{2}, which just means we go once more around the origin in the counterclockwise direction. Or we may have that the argument is \frac{-3\pi}{2} if we go in the opposite direction. See figure FIXME.
FIXME: draw figure

We are really just looking at polar coordinates that you know and love from calculus. If z=x+iy is of modulus r and argument \theta, then
x = r \cos \theta, \qquad y = r \sin \theta.
Therefore we have the following formula for the argument
\cos \theta = \frac{x}{\abs{z}}, \qquad \sin \theta = \frac{y}{\abs{z}} .
Of course \theta is only defined up to a multiple of 2\pi as are all angles in the plane. We write the argument as
\arg z = \theta .
Notice also that 0 has no reasonable argument, just as for polar coordinates we could not write an angle.
FIXME: DRAW and examples

Since the argument is not a unique number it is sometimes conventient to restrict it to a range in which it is unique. Since adding 2\pi changes nothing, it is always possible to give the argument \theta such that -\pi \lt \theta \leq \pi. We call this number the principal valueprincipal valueSome authors prefer the principlan value to be 0 \leq \theta \lt 2\pi, although this turns out to be inconvenient in some calculations. or principal branchprincipal branch of the argument and to distinguish we usually write it as \Arg z rather than just \arg z.

subsection.title: Exponential
subsection.p:
If z has modulus r and argument \theta then we can write
z= r (\cos \theta + i \sin \theta ) .
Let us give a name to the expression in the parenthesis. Let us write
e^{i \theta} = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta .
This extends the definition of the exponential to the imaginary numbers. To extend to all complex numbers, we recall the laws of exponents and we wish our new extension to also satisfy these laws. It therefore makes sense to define for z=x+iy:
e^z = e^{x+iy} = e^x e^{iy} = e^x ( \cos y + i \sin y ) .
FIXME: examples

The exponential satisfies many useful properties. Let us list some that are easy to verify from the definition and from properties of the real exponential, the sine, and the cosine.
e^{z+w} = e^ze^w, \qquad e^{-w} = \frac{1}{e^w}, \qquad e^{z-w} = \frac{e^z}{e^w},
\overline{e^{z}} = e^{\bar{z}} , \qquad \abs{e^{x+iy}} = e^x ,
and for any integer k:
e^{z} = e^{z+2\pi i} = e^{z-2\pi i} = e^{z+4\pi i} = e^{z+2k\pi i} .

The exponential function plays a central role in this subject and we will see it often. Let us first notice that it gives a convenient way of writing a complex number using the polar coordinates:
z = re^{i\theta} .
And using the properties of the exponential we find that multiplication is more convenient in the polar coordinates. Let z = re^{i\theta} and w = se^{i\eta}. Then
zw = ( re^{i\theta} ) ( se^{i\eta} ) = (rs) e^{i(\theta+\eta)} .
So in polar coordinates when we multiply complex numbers we multiply the moduli and we add the arguments.

This last property gives an interpretation of the complex number multiplication as dilation and rotation around the origin. That is, multiplying by re^{i\theta} dilates by factor of r and rotates by angle \theta. In particular, since i = e^{i\pi/2}, and \pi/2 = 90^\circ, we see that multiplying by i rotates around the origin by 90^\circ.

subsection.title: Roots of Unity
subsection.p:
We have mentioned that complex numbers always provide exactly the right number of roots to polynomial equations. Let us consider the equation
z^d = 1 .
Clearly z=1 is a solution. But we claim there are always exactly d distinct solutions. First let us see what happens when we take a power. Write z = r e^{i \theta}. Then
z^d = r^d {(e^{i \theta})}^d = r^d e^{id\theta} .
So now suppose that
z^d = r^d e^{id\theta} = 1 .
Two points in the plane are equal means their moduli (distance to origin) are equal, so r^d = 1, and there is only one nonnegative real number r solving this equation, and that is r=1.

It is a little bit more difficult with the argument. The argument is only determined up to adding a multiple of 2\pi. The argument of 1 is 0 or 2\pi or any other multiple of 2\pi. So e^{id\theta} = 1 if there exists some integer k such that
d\theta = 2k \pi, \qquad \text{or} \qquad \theta = \frac{k}{d} 2 \pi .
We notice that for k=0,1,2,\ldots,d-1 we obtain different \theta between 0 and 2\pi. For any other k we could add and subtract a multiple of 2\pi and get into the previous situation. Hence the \theta are
0 , \frac{1}{d} 2 \pi , \frac{2}{d} 2 \pi , \ldots, \frac{d-1}{d} 2 \pi .
In other words, the d roots are
1, e^{i2\pi/d}, e^{i4\pi/d}, \ldots, e^{i2(d-1)\pi/d} .
These are called the dth roots of unityroots of unity.

For example, if d=3, the third roots of unity, that is the three solutions to z^3=1 are
1, e^{i2\pi/3}, e^{i4\pi/3} .
If d=4, the fourth roots of unity, that is the four solutions to z^4=1 are
1, e^{i\pi/2}, e^{i\pi}, e^{i3\pi/2}, \qquad \text{or} \qquad 1, i, -1, -i .

section.p:
Before we study functions on the complex plane, we need to have language to describe subsets in the complex plane, as functions are often not going to be defined on the entire plane. Sets are often described the in the notation:
X = \{ z \in \C : \text{some condition on } z \} .
which translates to the set of all z that satisfies the condition given. FIXME: We use the notation X \subset \C. FIXME: also the notation z \in X.

section.title: Limits
section.p:
If we have an expression or a function of a complex variable, we may wish to take a limit as a complex variable z goes to some fixed complex value z_0. That is we may wish to compute the limit
\lim_{z \to z_0} f(z) .

The definition of a limit is the following: Suppose the domain of f(z) is D and the point z_0 is in D or on the boundary of D. A complex number L is a limit of f(z) as z\to z_0 or
\lim_{z \to z_0} f(z) = L ,
if for all \epsilon > 0 there exists a \delta > 0 such that
f(z) \in \Delta_\epsilon\bigl(f(z_0)\bigr), \text{ for all } z \in \Delta_\delta^*(z_0) .
or in other words if
f\bigl(\Delta_\delta^*(z_0)\bigr) \subset \Delta_\epsilon\bigl(f(z_0)\bigr) .
FIXME: draw, note that approach is arbitrary
The limit does not always exist, but if it does it is unique (theorem).

theorem.p:
Suppose f(z) \to L and g(z)\to M as z \to z_0. Then as z \to z_0.
f(z)+g(z) \to L+M
f(z)g(z) \to LM
If M\not=0, then \frac{f(z)}{g(z)} \to \frac{L}{M}.

section.p:
Examples: 1,z,... as z \to z_0. (z^2+1)/(z-1), z\to 1. 1/z, z\to 0, note that if z = re^{i\theta} then 1/z = (1/r)e^{-i\theta}, so
|1/z - L| = |(1/r)e^{-i\theta}-L| \geq |(1/r)e^{-i\theta}| - |L| = 1/r - |L|
so
|1/z - L| + |L| \geq 1/r \to \infty
So |1/z - L| not only doesn't go to zero, it becomes arbitrarily large.
Thm: f(z) \to L if and only if u \to \Re L and v \to \Im L.

Examples: \frac{z}{\bar{z}} = \frac{z^2}{z\bar{z}} = \frac{x^2-y^2}{x^2+y^2} + i\frac{2xy}{x^2+y^2} limit does not exist for these. Another way to see it, approach along real axis, then it is one as \bar{z} = z, then along imaginary axis where \bar{z} = -z

A function f is continuouscontinuous at z_0 if
\lim_{z \to z_0} f(z) = f(z_0) .
A function is simply continuous if it is continuous at all points.

theorem.p: If f and g are continuous so is f+g, fg, \frac{f}{g} (provided g is not zero).

section.p: Examples: 1, z, z^2, \bar{z} any polynomial, e^z, 1/z on \C\setminus \{0\}.

theorem.p: If f is continuous at z_0 and g is continuous at f(z_0), then the composition g \circ f is continuous at z_0.

section.p: Examples: e^{z^2}, etc...

theorem.p: f = u+iv is continuous if and only u and v are continuous.

section.title: Complex Derivative
section.p: Looks similar to real one variable derivative, but looks can be deceiving. In fact sometimes it is just called the derivativederivative.
Examples: 1, z, z^2. \frac{(z+\Delta)^2 -z^2}{\Delta} = \frac{2z \Delta+\Delta^2}{\Delta} = 2z+\Delta.

On the other hand \bar{z} has no complex derivative anywhere: \frac{\overline{z+\Delta} -\bar{z}}{\Delta} = \frac{\bar{\Delta}}{\Delta}
and we know this has no limit as \Delta \to 0.

Thm: if f and g have a complex derivative, then
(f+g)' = f'+g'
(fg)' = f'g + fg'
(f/g)' = (f'g - fg')/(g^2) ... g \not= 0
(f(g(z))' = f'(g(z))g'(z) ( = f'g')

Example: Since 1,z, have complex derivative all all points, then so do all their algebraic combinations. So all polynomials in z are complex differentiable, and their derivative works similarly: FIXME: example.
Similarly rational functions P(z)/Q(z) are complex differentiable outside the points where Q(z)=0. FIXME: example.
A complex function f defined on a domain U (open connected set) is said to be analyticanalytic if f is complex differentiable at all points of U.
Example: z^2 is analytic, but z\bar{z} is complex differentiable at 0 but nowhere else, so it is not analytic on any open set.
Example: polynomials and rational functions are complex differentiable at all points, they are analytic.

\Re z, \Im z do not have complex derivative as \Re z = \frac{1}{2} (z+\bar{z}), \Im z = \frac{1}{2i}(z-\bar{z}) and while z has complex derivative everywhere \bar{z} does not. So polynomials in x and y are not necessarily analytic. In fact we have the following lemma:

lemma.p: Every polynomial P(x,y) = c_{00} + c_{10} x + c_{01} y + c_{20} x^2 + c_{11} xy + \cdots in x and y can be rewritten in terms of z and \bar{z}. If all the parenthesis are expanded P contains no \bar{z}, then P is analytic. If there are \bar{z}'s left, then P is not analytic.

example.p:
On the other hand
x^2+y^2 = {\left( \frac{z+\bar{z}}{2} \right)}^2 + {\left( \frac{z-\bar{z}}{2i} \right)}^2 = \cdots = z \bar{z} .
So this polynomial is not analytic.

section.title: Cauchy-Riemann Equations
section.p:
Let u_x, u_y, v_x, v_y be the real partial derivatives in x and y. E.g.
u_x(x,y) = \lim_{\delta \to 0} \frac{u(x+\delta,y)-u(x,y)}{\delta} .
where the limit is the real limit, that is \delta is real, not complex.

If f complex differentiable, then the two expressions for the complex derivative f'(z) must of course be equal, or in other words:
u_x = v_y, \qquad v_x = -u_y .
These equations are called the Cauchy-Riemann equations CR equations Cauchy-Riemann (CR) equations.
If we apply the above calculation at every point we find one direction of the following theorem.

theorem.p: A function f defined on a domain U is analytic if and only if the Cauchy-Riemann equations hold for all points in U.

section.p: It is generally much easier to check that a function is analytic by checking the Cauchy-Riemman equations rather than by computing the limit.

section.title: Elementary Functions
section.p:
The first type of elementary functions we discuss are the so called affine functionaffine functions. That if f(z) = az+b for some complex numbers a and b. When b=0, then f is said to be linear functionlinearOften, expecially in calculus, affine functions are also called linear.. For example,
f(z) = 3iz-\sqrt{2} + 9i
is an affine function, and
f(z) = (1+i)z
is a linear funtion.

f(z) = \frac{2i+8z}{1+(1+i)z} .
An affine function is a special kind of a linear fractional function: we take c=1 and d=0.

Exponential e^z. Properties
e^z \not= 0, e^0=1, \frac{d}{dz} e^z = e^z, e^{z+w} = e^ze^w, \overline{e^z} = e^{\bar{z}}, e^z=e^{z+2\pi ki}, \abs{e^z} = e^{\Re z}, \arg e^z = \Im z
Let's show the derivative. We know it's complex differentiable we might as well just differentiate in x. So
\frac{d}{dz} e^z = \frac{d}{dx} e^x (\cos y + i \sin y) = e^x (\cos y + i \sin y) = e^z
Infinitely many to one. Always infinitely many roots of e^z = w. Unlike the real exponential. Example e^z = 1 has solution z=0, but also z=2\pi ki for any integer k.

Logarithm is the inverse of the exponential. Of course as the exponential is infinitely many to one, the logarithm is not a well defined function. It is an infinitely many valued function. That is we wish to say that if e^z = w, then
\log w = z
but we also get that
\log w = z + 2\pi k i
for any integer k. other properties that follow is that \log 0 is undefined. and the corresponding properties from the exponential
\log 1 = 2 \pi i k, \log z + \log w = \log zw, \log z = \log z + 2\pi ki
Since
z = e^{\log z}, \qquad \text{then} \qquad 1 = \frac{d}{dz} e^{\log z} = \left( \frac{d}{dz} \log z \right) e^{\log z} \left( \frac{d}{dz} \log z \right) z
so
\frac{d}{dz} \log z = \frac{1}{z}
as expected.

Just as we have the principal branch of arg, called Arg, that is valued in -\pi \lt \Arg z \leq \pi we have the principal branch of the log, called Log defined by
\Log z = \log \abs{z} + i \Arg z
This is usually what the computers will compute if you plug a complex number into log. It is a single valued function, but it is not continuous along the negative reals. DRAW, explain. Now a different branch could have been picked for the argument, such as taking the argument in the range [0,2\pi) which would be another fine choice and then the logarithm you get is not continuous on the positive reals. Any choice you make will be discontonious somewhere if you want a function. We will see that this is not a defect, this is really what makes complex analysis so useful. One says that log is an analytic multivalued function defined on the punctured plane. But if we want an actual analytic function, we must make a cut...

Finally let's define trig functions. We have that
e^{it} = \cos t + i \sin t \qquad e^{-it} = \cos t - i \sin t
We could say: let this also hold for complex t. And then we have
\cos z = \frac{e^{iz} + e^{-iz}}{2} \qquad \sin z = \frac{e^{iz} - e^{-iz}}{2i}
And these are the definitions of comlex sine and cosine. When z is real, these are the standard sin and cosine for real numbers.
\cos (-z) = \cos z, \sin(-z) = - \sin z,
0 = \cos z, \qquad \text{for} z = k \pi
0 = \sin z, \qquad \text{for} z = k \pi + \pi/2
(\cos z)^2 + (\sin z)^2 = 1
Actually all the standard identities hold. The moment we have an identity for all real numbers it turns out it holds for all complex numbers too.

section.title: Harmonic Functions
section.p:
A function u in the plane is harmonic if it satisfies the Laplace equationLaplace equation
\Delta u = u_{xx}+u_{yy} = 0 . Harmonic functions come up in many energy minimizing steady state problems, for example in solving for the stady state heat distribution in a medium.
Examples x, x^2-y^2, xy, ...
FIXME: Visualize harmonic functions.
Maximum principle: If u is harmonic on a domain (connected open set) D and achieves a maximum in D, then u is constant. That is, harmonic functions are all saddle surfaces at best.

theorem.p: The real and imaginary parts of an analytic function are harmonic.

section.p:
To see the theorem, we take the Cauchy Riemann equations
u_x = v_y, \qquad u_y = - v_x ,
and we differentiate them. The first equation we differentiate in x and the second we differentiate in y:
u_{xx} = v_{xy}, \qquad u_{yy} = - v_{xy} .
So
u_{xx} + u_{yy} = v_{xy} - v_{xy} = 0 .
Similarly
v_{xx} + v_{yy} = 0
FIXME: Define harmonic conjugateharmonic conjugate of u.

example.p:
Example: u = x^2-y^2 is harmonic. Then as u_x = v_y, then
2x = v_y
so perhaps v = 2xy would work? It satisfies u_x = v_y of course, and we can also check that it satisfies u_y = -v_x.

Example: \log \abs{z} is harmonic, but no harmonic conjugate exists in \C \setminus \{ 0 \}. For example
\Log z = \log \abs{z} + i \Arg z
but \Arg z is not defined in the entire punctured plane. FIXME: DRAW.

section.p: Thm: Suppose R = \{ (x,y) | a \lt x \lt b, c \lt y \lt d \} and u is harmonic in R. Then there exists a harmonic conjugate v defined on R.

Let's just compute it: Suppose (x_0,y_0) is a point in R then as u_x = v_y,
v(x,y) = \int_{y_0}^y u_x(x,t)\, dt + C(x)
Now as v_x = -u_y we have that
-u_y(x,y) = v_x(x,y) = \int_{y_0}^y u_{xx}(x,t)\, dt + C'(x) = \int_{y_0}^y - u_{yy}(x,t)\, dt + C'(x) = -u_y(x,y)+u_y(x,y_0)
so u_y(x,y_0) = -C'(x) and so
C(x) = \int_{x_0}^x -u_y(s,y_0) \, ds + D
So
v(x,y) = \int_{y_0}^y u_x(x,t)\, dt + \int_{x_0}^x -u_y(s,y_0) \, ds + D
We have not only figured out how to construct the complex conjugate we have also figured out that any two complex conjugates differ by a constat (D).
